SqlFileStream.summary: Exposes SQL Server data that is stored with the FILESTREAM column attribute as a sequence of bytes.

remarks.format:
The <xref:Microsoft.Data.SqlTypes.SqlFileStream> class is used to work with `varbinary(max)` data stored with the FILESTREAM attribute in a SQL Server 2008 database. You must install the .NET Framework 3.5 SP1 (or later) to use <xref:Microsoft.Data.SqlTypes.SqlFileStream> to work with FILESTREAM data.
Specifying the FILESTREAM attribute on a `varbinary(max)` column causes SQL Server to store the data in the local NTFS file system instead of in the database file. Transact-SQL statements provide data manipulation capabilities within the server, and Win32 file system interfaces provide streaming access to the data.
> [!NOTE] > Individual files stored in a FILESTREAM column cannot be opened directly from the NTFS file system. Streaming FILESTREAM data works only in the context of a SQL Server transaction.
The <xref:Microsoft.Data.SqlTypes.SqlFileStream> class is derived from the <xref:System.IO.Stream> class, which represents an abstraction of a sequence of bytes from some arbitrary data source such as a file or a block of memory. You can read from a FILESTREAM by transferring data from a stream into a data structure such as an array of bytes. You can write to a FILESTREAM by transferring the data from a data structure into a stream. You can also seek within the stream, which allows you to query and modify data at the current position within the stream.
For conceptual documentation and code examples, see [FILESTREAM Data](https://learn.microsoft.com/sql/connect/ado-net/sql/filestream-data).
For documentation about setting up and configuring FILESTREAM data on SQL Server, see [Designing and Implementing FILESTREAM Storage](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=121499) in SQL Server 2008 Books Online.

SqlFileStream.seealso: SQL Server Binary and Large-Value Data (ADO.NET)

ctor1.param: The logical path to the file. The path can be retrieved by using the Transact-SQL Pathname function on the underlying FILESTREAM column in the table.
The transaction context for the object. Applications should return the byte array returned by calling the GET_FILESTREAM_TRANSACTION_CONTEXT method.

param.name: access
param.para: The access mode to use when opening the file. Supported enumeration values are , , and .
When using , the object can be used to read all the existing data.
When using , points to a zero byte file. Existing data will be overwritten when the object is closed and the transaction is committed.

When using , the points to a file which has all the existing data in it. The handle is positioned at the beginning of the file. You can use one of the methods to move the handle position within the file to write or append new data.

ctor1.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: The following table lists the code access security (CAS) permissions that all callers in the stack must have to use the constructors.
For more information about CAS, see Code Access Security and ADO.NET.
If an exception is thrown, any open transactions should be rolled back. Otherwise, data loss can occur.

ctor1.exception: is a null reference, or is null.

exception.para: is an empty string (""), contains only white space, or contains one or more invalid characters. begins with "\\\\.\\", for example "\\\\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0 ".
The handle returned by the call to NTCreateFile is not of type FILE_TYPE_DISK. contains an unsupported value.

ctor1.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.
The specified is invalid, such as being on an unmapped drive.
The access requested is not permitted by the operating system for the specified path. This occurs when Write or ReadWrite access is specified, and the file or directory is set for read-only access.
NtCreateFile fails with error code set to ERROR_SHARING_VIOLATION.

ctor2.param: The logical path to the file. The path can be retrieved by using the Transact-SQL Pathname function on the underlying FILESTREAM column in the table.

The transaction context for the object. When set to null, an implicit transaction will be used for the object. Applications should return the byte array returned by calling the GET_FILESTREAM_TRANSACTION_CONTEXT method.

The access mode to use when opening the file. Supported enumeration values are , , and . When using , the object can be used to read all the existing data. When using , points to a zero byte file. Existing data will be overwritten when the object is closed and the transaction is committed. When using , the points to a file which has all the existing data in it. The handle is positioned at the beginning of the file. You can use one of the methods to move the handle position within the file to write or append new data.
Specifies the option to use while opening the file. Supported values are , , , and .
The allocation size to use while creating a file. If set to 0, the default value is used.
ctor2.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: The following table lists the code access security (CAS) permissions that all callers in the stack must have to use the SqlFileStream constructors.
For more information about CAS, see Code Access Security and ADO.NET.
If an exception is thrown, any open transactions should be rolled back. Otherwise, data loss can occur.

ctor2.exception: is a null reference, or is null.

exception.para: is an empty string (""), contains only white space, or contains one or more invalid characters. begins with "\\\\.\\", for example "\\\\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0 "
The handle returned by call to NTCreateFile is not of type FILE_TYPE_DISK. contains an unsupported value.

ctor2.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.
The specified is invalid, such as being on an unmapped drive.
The access requested is not permitted by the operating system for the specified path. This occurs when Write or ReadWrite access is specified, and the file or directory is set for read-only access.
NtCreateFile fails with error code set to ERROR_SHARING_VIOLATION.

BeginRead.param: The buffer to read the data into.
The byte offset in at which to begin writing data read from the stream.
The maximum number of bytes to read.
An optional asynchronous callback, to be called when the read is complete.
A user-provided object that distinguishes this particular asynchronous read request from other requests
BeginRead.returns: An that represents the asynchronous read, which could still be pending.
BeginRead.remarks: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports reading.
BeginRead.exception: Reading data is not supported on the stream.

BeginWrite.param: The buffer to write data from.
The byte offset in from which to begin writing.
The maximum number of bytes to write.
An optional asynchronous callback, to be called when the write is complete.
A user-provided object that distinguishes this particular asynchronous write request from other requests.
BeginWrite.returns: An that represents the asynchronous write, which could still be pending.
BeginWrite.remarks: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports writing.
BeginWrite.exception: Writing data is not supported on the stream.

CanRead.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current stream supports reading.
CanRead.value: if the current stream supports reading; otherwise, .

CanSeek.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current stream supports seeking.
CanSeek.value: if the current stream supports seeking; otherwise, .

CanTimeout.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current stream can time out.
CanTimeout.value: if the current stream can time out; otherwise, .

CanWrite.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current stream supports writing.
CanWrite.value: if the current stream supports writing; otherwise, .

dtor.summary: Destructor of the SqlFileStream class object.

Dispose.param: to release managed and unmanaged resources; to release only unmanaged resources.
Dispose.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used and optionally releases the managed resources.

EndRead.param: The reference to the pending asynchronous request to finish.
EndRead.summary: Waits for the pending asynchronous read to complete.
EndRead.returns: The number of bytes read from the stream, between zero (0) and the number of bytes you requested. Streams return zero (0) only at the end of the stream, otherwise, they should block until at least one byte is available.
EndRead.exception: The object did not come from the corresponding method.

EndWrite.param: A reference to the outstanding asynchronous I/O request.
EndWrite.exception: The object did not come from the corresponding method.

Finalize.summary: Ensures that resources are freed and other cleanup operations are performed when the garbage collector reclaims the .

Flush.summary: Clears all buffers for this stream and causes any buffered data to be written to the underlying device.

Length.summary: Gets a value indicating the length of the current stream in bytes.
Length.value: An indicating the length of the current stream in bytes.

Name.summary: Gets the logical path of the passed to the constructor.
Name.value: A string value indicating the name of the .

Position.summary: Gets or sets the position within the current stream.

Read.param: An array of bytes. When this method returns, the buffer contains the specified byte array with the values between offset and (offset + count - 1) replaced by the bytes read from the current source.
The zero-based byte offset in buffer at which to begin storing the data read from the current stream.
The maximum number of bytes to be read from the current stream.
Read.summary: Reads a sequence of bytes from the current stream and advances the position within the stream by the number of bytes read.
Read.returns: The total number of bytes read into the buffer. This can be less than the number of bytes requested if that many bytes are not currently available, or zero (0) if the end of the stream has been reached.
Read.remarks: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports writing.
Read.exception: The object does not support reading of data.

ReadByte.summary: Reads a byte from the stream and advances the position within the stream by one byte, or returns -1 if at the end of the stream.
ReadByte.returns: The unsigned byte cast to an , or -1 if at the end of the stream.
ReadByte.remarks: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports reading.
ReadByte.exception: The object does not support reading of data.

ReadTimeout.summary: Gets or sets a value, in milliseconds, that determines how long the stream will attempt to read before timing out.
ReadTimeout.value: A value, in milliseconds, that determines how long the stream will attempt to read before timing out.

Seek.param: A byte offset relative to the parameter
A value of type indicating the reference point used to obtain the new position
Seek.summary: Sets the position within the current stream.
Seek.returns: The new position within the current stream.

SetLength.param: The desired length of the current stream in bytes.
SetLength.summary: Sets the length of the current stream.
SetLength.remarks: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports reading.
SetLength.exception: The object does not support reading of data.

TransactionContext.summary: Gets or sets the transaction context for this object.
TransactionContext.value: The TransactionContext array that was passed to the constructor for this object.

Write.param: An array of bytes. This method copies bytes from to the current stream.
The zero-based byte offset in at which to begin copying bytes to the current stream.
The number of bytes to be written to the current stream.
Write.summary: Writes a sequence of bytes to the current stream and advances the current position within this stream by the number of bytes written.
Write.remarks: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports writing.
Write.exception: The object does not support writing of data.

WriteByte.param: The byte to write to the stream.
WriteByte.summary: Writes a byte to the current position in the stream and advances the position within the stream by one byte.
WriteByte.remarks: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports writing.
WriteByte.exception: The object does not support writing of data.

WriteTimeout.summary: Gets or sets a value, in milliseconds, that determines how long the stream will attempt to write before timing out.
WriteTimeout.value: A value, in milliseconds, that determines how long the stream will attempt to write before timing out.
